posts.cooked:
Our team has been using Rev MaxSwerve for the past two years, encountering frequent issues with the Neo 550 and Spark Max motor controllers. A common problem arises when the encoder wires run through the motor coils, causing the insulation to melt due to extreme heat. This results in a short circuit sending 12 volts through the encoder wire, permanently damaging the Spark Max.

We consulted with the Rev team, who identified that the Neo 550 may not correctly receive smart current limit settings, contributing to overheating issues. They recommended using SparkFlex with a Spark Flex Dock, which includes a failsafe feature to protect against damage. However, this solution is more expensive than using a Spark Max.

Exploring alternatives, we considered employing the Neo 550's onboard temperature sensor to monitor and shut off the motor if temperatures exceed safe levels. The Rev team noted delays in detecting high temperatures due to sensor latency, suggesting possible methods like monitoring temperature rate changes or reducing detection windows. This approach could provide a cost-effective solution without replacing the Spark Max entirely.

We are now investigating whether such temperature monitoring systems can effectively prevent damage while maintaining reliability. Additionally, we are interested in learning if other teams have successfully addressed similar issues, possibly with novel solutions that balance cost-effectiveness and performance.

link_counts.title: NEO short circuit resources (killing Spark MAX)

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: One of the problems with your suggested solution is that the temperature sensor inside NEO and/or NEO550 motors isn't close enough to the hot parts, such as the windings that can melt or short the encoder wire. While it might still be possible to use the sensor, setting a safe cutoff would require adjusting the threshold significantly lower than what the sensor actually reads. For instance, if the sensor indicates 100°, but the actual temperature is higher, around 150°, you'd need to set your cutoff at 60° to ensure safety.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: We’ve never seen this issue. What are you currently setting your limits at?

posts.name: Sophia
posts.cooked: I think I've made some progress with the temperature control system for our 550-series motors. By carefully monitoring and controlling the current input, we successfully kept the temperatures within a specific range, preventing overheating and improving efficiency. However, when I applied similar logic to the 700-series motors, designed for higher torque and current, the results were different. These motors don't respond the same way to temperature changes, and adjusting the current doesn't affect the temperature as expected. This makes me wonder if there are inherent design differences, such as cooling channels, insulation, or winding materials, that influence their thermal behavior. In the meantime, I'll continue refining the temperature control algorithms for the 700-series, possibly experimenting with cooling methods and additional sensors, with the hope of finding a solution.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: about where we're using 550s. We only use them in low-torque applications with a significant gear ratio and make sure that it won’t have to stall to do whatever it needs to do. Maxswerve it’s unavoidable to use Neo 550s, unless someone’s tried banebots 550s.
Our turn motor is driven by the gearing provided by Rev for the MAXSwerve kit. I don’t think the gearing is the problem, though—if it is, Rev shipped a product knowing it would fail.
